summary: The Supreme Court of India has held that a Special Civil Application under Articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution is not maintainable where the court or tribunal whose order is sought to be quashed is not impleaded as a party to the proceedings. summary: The appellants, ostensibly small scale shopkeepers located in Shirdi Nagar Panchayaat & Anr on the outskirts of the city, have moved the Supreme Court against the decision of the High Court to grant FSI to them. The Shirdi Sanctum Sanctorum of Shri Sai Baba, Shirdi, Maharashtra, in the year 1974 was a major pilgrimage destination for millions of devotees from all over the world. A compromise was reached between the appellants and the Sansthan of Shirdi on the issue of temporarily rehabilitating the appellants in a triangular space in the land of the same survey number by resorting to lottery.

summary: The appellants have moved the Supreme Court against the order of the High Court of Allahabad which had allowed the writ proceedings against the non-official respondents. The Allahabad High Court has ruled in favour of three brothers, Jagannath, Amar Nath and Raj Nath, in a dispute over a piece of land. The appellants before the Writ Court advanced a submission that as per Hindu law Kanhai was not excluded from the inheritance of his brother Bechai and his illegitimate children born to Smt. Ram Pyari were entitled to inherit the estate of Kanhai under the Hindu law and they would have priority in the matter of inheritance of Kanhai as against his brother’s sons.

summary: The appellants in this case have been granted leave to appeal against the orders of the High Court of Bombay Bench at Aurangabad. The appellants were appointed as Law Officers/Law Instructors by the State of Maharashtra in the year 2006 under the Government Resolution dated 21.08.2006 and the clauses 'A', 'B', and 'C' in the Government Resolution dated 15.9.2006 suffered from arbitrariness and unreasonableness. The High Court of Maharashtra has ruled that the posts created in various cadres including Legal Advisors, Law Officers and Law Instructors should be filled on contractual basis.

summary: Two separate appeals have been heard by the Kerala High Court against an order of the Administrative Tribunal, Ernakulam, which held that the age limit for appointment to the post of Village Postman and Mail Guards was not permissible as well as for reservation against the Other Backward Classes (OBC) category. A writ petition has been filed in the High Court of Kerala challenging the correctness of the order of the Kerala Public Service Tribunal in a case relating to the appointment of Extra Departmental Agents to the post of Postman. The Supreme Court of India is hearing the appeal of the Union of India and some of the respondents against a verdict of the Kerala High Court holding that the appointment of the appellants to the post of Postman is by way of direct recruitment or by promotion.

summary: The appellants in this appeal have been convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment for offences punishable under Sections 302 and 364 read with Section 34 of the Indian Penal Code (hereinafter referred to as 'IPC') and all three of them have been directed to undergo sentence of life imprisonment for the charge under Section 302 IPC and ten years in respect of the charge under Section 364 IPC read with Section 34 IPC. The prosecution alleges that on the night of 06.06.2000, Prabhavati, a resident of Mysore, was found dead in the bedroom of A-1. summary: The Madhya Pradesh High Court has questioned the validity of the Madhya Pradesh Private Medical and Dental Post Graduate Courses Entrance Examination Rules, 2009 which have been framed by the State. The appellants have challenged the constitutional validity of the Madhya Pradesh Professional Educational Institutions Act, 2007 as well as the Madhya Pradesh Professional Educational Institutions Rules, 2008 and Rules, 2009 on the ground of violation of Article 19(1)(g) of the Constitution as well as on the ground of infringement of their right to education. As per the Madhya Pradesh Professional Educational Institutions (Reservation in Admissions) Act, 2007 the State Government may, by notification, make Rules for carrying out the purpose of the Act and the Rules made thereunder, inter alia, relating to the eligibility of admission, manner admission and allocation of seats in a professional educational institution.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has issued a series of notices to the State of Maharashtra on appeals against the common impugned judgment and order passed by the Division Bench of High Court of Judicature at Bombay, Nagpur Bench, Nagpur in various Writ Petitions including Writ Petition No.1034 of 1995, wherein the High Court has dismissed all the writ petitions. The appellant-trust was formed under the National Institute of Technology (NIT) Act, 1956 to promote and promote the cause of higher education in the State of Maharashtra. It was contended by the learned senior counsel that the High Court has erred in holding that respondent no.1-NIT cannot acquire any land by incorporating a clause like the impugned clause contained in the development agreement, in the instant case, which has been executed between itself and the land owners to the effect that the land owners shall transfer the land developed by them for public utility purpose, free of cost and without getting any compensation from the NIT.

summary: This appeal is filed against the final order passed by the High Court of Income-tax, Rajasthan, in 1986 relating to the assessment year 1978-79. The issue before the High Court of Rajasthan was as to whether the rental income from Umed Bhawan Palace, Jaipur, by way of rent to the Defence Ministry, is taxable in the hands of the appellant or is confined only to that portion of palace which is in his actual occupation as residence and the rest which is in occupation of the tenant. This is an appeal against an order of the Gujarat High Court which held that, when a ruler lets out a portion of his palace for his own use, he is not entitled to the benefit of exemption available under Section 10(19A) for the entire palace.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that an insurance company cannot be held liable for the death of a person in a road accident. The appellant and the claimants have challenged the order of the High Court of India which held United India Insurance Company Ltd. The Supreme Court has held that the driver of the offending vehicle was holding a valid driving license (Exhibit-R1) at the time of accident and since the Insurance Company failed to prove otherwise, it was liable to pay the compensation awarded by the Tribunal and enhanced by the High Court.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that the power of the State to acquire land for a public purpose has been used in the present case to facilitate transfer of title of the land of original owners to a private builder to advance the business interest of the said builder. summary: In our series of letters from Indian journalists, film-maker and columnist Damodar Lal reflects on the plight of a poor landlord languishing in courts for over fourty years. In Damodar Lal vs Sohan Devi And Ors, the High Court has held that the finding of material alteration in a suit for eviction is totally perverse and not based upon sound and trustworthy evidence. The Court of Appeal in Kanoon has held that the High Court in second appeal was not justified in upsetting the finding which was a pure question of fact.

summary: The Gujarat High Court has ruled that the tariff fixed by the Gujarat Electricity Regulatory Commission for procurement of electricity by the Solar Energy Distribution Licensees in the State of Gujarat did not take into account the benefit of accelerated depreciation under the Income Tax Act and Rules. A solar power project was commissioned by the 1st respondent on 2.3.2012, beyond the “control period” specified in the said PPA. An appeal has been filed in the Supreme Court against a decision of the Gujarat State Electricity Regulatory Commission (GSERC) to impose tariff of Rs.15 per kWh for first 12 years and thereafter Rs.5 per kWh from 13th year to 25th year, provided the Solar Project is commissioned on or before 31st December 2011.

summary: An appeal has been filed in the High Court of Bihar against the judgment of the trial court declaring the property of Tarawati Devi as property of Umashanker Prasad. Two sisters Dhanukdhari Sahay and Tarawati Devi filed a suit against the first respondent-Defendant Tej Pratap Narayan and the second respondent-Defendant Girish Chandra Prasad alleging that they were the rightful owners of the disputed property. summary: The Punjab and Haryana High Court has set aside the conviction and sentence of a former employee of the Punjab State Corporation for offences punishable under the Indian Penal Code, 1860. Section 409 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) prohibits the commission of offence by a public servant in discharge of his official duty, but restricts its scope to only those acts or omissions, which are done by a public servant in discharge of official duty. The Supreme Court has ruled that no sanction should be required in case of judges and public servants accused of any offence alleged to have been committed while acting or purporting to act in the discharge of their official duty, except with the previous sanction of the Central Government.

summary: The Supreme Court has held that the acquisition of land by the government under the emergency clause of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894, may not be quashed even after the expiry of four years. Section 24 of the Land Acquisition Act, 2013 provides as follows: “Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act, any land acquisition proceedings initiated under the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 (1 of 1894), where an award under the said section 11 has been made five years or more prior to the commencement of this Act but the physical possession of the land has not been taken or the compensation has not been paid the said proceedings shall be deemed to have lapsed and the appropriate Government, if it so chooses, shall initiate the proceedings of such land acquisition afresh in accordance with the provisions of this Act.”

summary: The Supreme Court of India has held that the High Court of Kerala had, relying upon Section 98(2) of the Travancore-Cochin High Court Act, confirmed the decree under appeal despite of opinion between the two Judges comprising the Bench on a question of fact. The Supreme Court has taken up the issue of reference to a Bench of 5 Judges to resolve the conflict arising between two judges of the High Court hearing an appeal, on a question of fact. In our considered opinion, the Travancore-Cochin Act and the Kerala Act are not Letters Patent of the High Court and therefore they cannot be held to have been saved under the provisions of sub-section (3) of Section 98 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

summary: The appellant is a widow and a government employee of the Government of Punjab and she has approached this Court with a grievance that she is not being paid full pension in accordance with the provisions of the Family Pension Scheme, 1964 (hereinafter referred to as ‘the scheme’). The appellant is the only person who is entitled to the pension as per the provisions of the aforestated scheme of the government of India, under which Shri Yash Pal was a member. The Supreme Court of India has ruled that family pension does not form part of the estate of the deceased and therefore, even an employee has no right to dispose of the same in his Will by giving a direction that someone other than the one who is entitled to it, should be given the same.

summary: A bench of the Supreme Court of India, headed by Chief Justice Dipak Misra, has ruled that the delay in filing of a Special Leave Petition (SLP) is "fit and proper" as it is a "beneficial legislation". The Gauhati High Court has allowed a writ petition and modified an Award passed by the Motor Accidents Tribunal, Gauhati, which ordered the insurer of a bus and the jeep involved in the accident to pay compensation to the survivors of the accident. The learned counsel submits that the writ petition filed by the respondent-Insurance Company before the single judge of the Kerala High Court is not maintainable.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that an insurance company cannot be held liable for the loss of a vehicle if the vehicle is involved in an accident. The State Commission for Protection of Consumer Rights has held that an insurance company should pay compensation to an insured person on the basis of the terms and conditions of the policy and not on the basis of the presence of more than one person in the vehicle. The appellant had filed a complaint against the respondent- Company, Reliance General Insurance, alleging violation of the terms and conditions of the insurance policy by allowing six passengers to travel in the vehicle when the permitted load was only 1+1.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has issued a notice to the State of Bihar on a criminal appeal filed by a Scheduled Caste (SC) man against a lower court's order dismissing his plea for quashing of an FIR registered against him under the Immoral Traffic (Prevention) Act, 1956. summary: The following is a list of all the cases heard in the Supreme Court of India in 2016. summary: The appellant has been granted leave to appeal against the order of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad which found him guilty of Criminal Contempt for intimidating and threatening a Civil Judge (Senior Division), Etah in his Court on 16.4.2003 and 13.5.2003. The appellant, Shri Mahipal Singh Rana, Advocate appeared before the Civil Judge (Senior Division), Etah on 5 July, 2016 and pleaded not guilty to the charge of criminal contempt of the High Court of Uttar Pradesh. On 16.4.2003, the learned Civil Judge (Senior Division), Etah wrote a letter to the Registrar-General of the High Court, giving some more facts regarding contempt behaviour of the appellant with a request to place the facts before the Hon’ble Chief Justice of the High Court so that appropriate action under the Act may be taken against the appellant.

summary: The appellant Bhupinder Singh Bawa has been granted leave to appeal against the final judgment and order of the High Court of Delhi which had ordered his eviction from the suit premises. The appellant has been occupying the premises of the respondent- Landlady for more than 10 years and has been running her sanitary and hardware business from the premises. The appellant made a case that the properties owned by the respondent were not suitable for running her son’s business as it was located on the main road and in a market area.

summary: Savelife Foundation & Anr vs Union Of India & Anr on 30 March, 2016 Equivalent citations: AIR 2016 SUPREME 1617, 2016 (7) 194, 2016 (3) ADR 368, AIRRUN SC (CIVIL) 2065, (2016) 4 JCR 167 (SC), (2016) 116 ALL LR 545, (2016) 3 KANT LJ 237 Good Samaritans are defined in the Indian constitution as “any person who lends emergency assistance or service to another person in good faith and who is not liable in civil damages with respect to his act or omission.” There is need to evolve the system by promptly providing effective care system with certain ethical and legal principles.

summary: The appellants-society have challenged the order of the School Tribunal, Nagpur which was pleased to set aside the termination with direction to reinstate respondent No. 4 and also pay back CIVIL Society, Tumsar And Ors vs State of Maharashtra And Ors on 1 February, 2016 Indian Kanoon - http://indiankanoon.org/doc/73809958/ 1wages for the intervening period. The High Court of Maharashtra has issued the following notice to the State of Maharashtra: The appellants had challenged the order of the Education Officer refusing to pay the back wages to the employee of the appellants who was terminated by the appellants and reinstated by the Management in pursuance of the final decision of the competent appellate authority of the Department.
